questions.text:
According to the NSQIP/AGS guidelines, severe nutritional risk in the geriatric population is present when unintended weight loss is ______________

NSQIP/AGS- National Surgical Quality Improvement Program/American Geriatrics Society.
questions.solution:
The NSQIP/AGS guidelines note a severe nutritional risk when unintended weight loss is greater than 10% within 6 months in the geriatric population.

As part of the preoperative evaluation for geriatric anaesthesia, nutritional screening is conducted as malnutrition is associated with adverse surgical outcomes. 

Severe nutritional risk is associated with:

  • Unintended weight loss is greater than 10% within 6 months 
  • Body mass index (BMI) < 18.5 kg/m2
  • Serum albumin < 3 g/dL

questions.text: What is the anticipated weight loss after delivery as a result of the expulsion of products of gestation and accompanying blood loss?
questions.solution:
There is a weight loss of 5-6 kgs due to the expulsion of products of gestation (fetus, placentae, liquor) and accompanying blood loss after delivery. 

This estimate includes the average weight of a full-term newborn (approximately 3-4 kgs), the placenta (roughly 0.5-1 kg), amniotic fluid (about 0.8-1 kg), and additional blood and fluid loss that occurs during delivery.

This weight loss may continue up to 6 months after delivery.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for evaluating a patient with unintentional weight loss?

choices.text: 25% of food left uneaten after 7 days

questions.solution:
Body mass index (BMI) of <21  kg/m2 is considered an indication for evaluating a patient with unintentional weight loss (UWL).

Indications of UWL include:

  • 5% weight loss in 30 days 
  • 10% weight loss in 180 days
  • Body mass index <21 kg/m2
  • 25% of food left uneaten after 7 days 
  • Change in fit of clothing
  • Change in appetite, smell, or taste 
  • Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, constipation, dysphagia 

A thorough history and physical examination, a complete blood count, tests for liver enzyme levels, C-reactive protein, ESR, renal function studies, thyroid function tests, chest radiography, and abdominal ultrasound are all part of the initial evaluation. Cancer screening tests, such as mammography and colonoscopy, should be performed.

All elderly patients with weight loss should undergo screening for dementia and depression by using instruments such as the Mini-Mental State Examination and the Geriatric Depression Scale, respectively. The Mini Nutritional Assessment and the Nutrition Screening Initiative are also available for the nutritional assessment of elderly patients

questions.text: An HIV patient presented with involuntary weight loss of >10% associated with chronic diarrhea for > 30 days. He was diagnosed with wasting syndrome. Which of the following is least likely to be responsible for weight loss in this patient?
questions.solution:
Wasting syndrome/ generalized wasting is an AIDS-defining condition associated with involuntary weight loss of >10% of body weight, fever and chronic diarrhoea lasting >30 days without any other cause. Lipoatrophy is not responsible for weight loss in this condition.

The majority of the weight loss in this condition is due to a loss of muscle mass, also known as lean body mass or body cell mass. Bioelectrical impedance analysis (BIA) or a full body x-ray (DEXA) scan is used to measure it.

A constant feature of this syndrome is severe muscle wasting with scattered myofiber degeneration and occasional evidence of myositis.

Glucocorticoids may be of some benefit. Androgenic steroids, growth hormone, and total parenteral nutrition have all been used as therapeutic interventions, with varying degrees of success.

Wasting syndrome is rarely seen nowadays due to the early initiation of antiretroviral drugs.

HIV-associated lipodystrophy is a side effect of antiretroviral therapy (ART) that occurs due to the redistribution of adipose tissue. It can manifest as fat accumulation (lipohypertrophy) or fat loss (lipoatrophy).

Lipoatrophy is characterised by subcutaneous fat loss in the face, arms, legs, abdomen, and/or buttocks. There is preferential fat loss with no evidence of muscle atrophy, which distinguishes it from AIDS-related wasting syndrome.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: You are assessing the risk of developing malnutrition in a patient with a history of unintentional weight loss using the Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool (MUST). What score is assigned to a patient who lost 4% of body weight in the last 6 months?
questions.solution:
According to the Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool (MUST), this patient is assigned a score of 0 for a 4% weight loss in the last 6 months.

MUST is a screening tool used to detect protein-energy malnutrition and identify people at risk of malnutrition. MUST uses three independent criteria to determine the overall risk of malnutrition: current weight status (calculated by BMI), unintentional weight loss, and acute disease effect. Each parameter has a rating of 0, 1, or 2.

Weight loss (over the last 3-6 months) is determined by reviewing the individual's medical record. If the patient is currently suffering from a pathophysiologic condition and has not consumed any food for more than 5 days, an acute disease factor is added.

Score  BMI Unintentional weight loss (last 3-6 months)
0 >20 (>30 obese) <5%
1 18.5-20 5-10% 
2 < 18.5 >10%

Acute disease effect: add 2. The overall risk for malnutrition is established as low (score = 0), medium (score = 1), or high (score > 2).

This screening tool's ability to be used in all healthcare settings and by adults of all ages is a significant advantage. It has good concurrent validity with the majority of other nutrition assessment tools tested and is quick and simple to use.

questions.text: A patient who presented with significant weight loss was started on parenteral nutrition, following which, he developed refeeding syndrome. What is the maximum nutritional support that should be started to prevent this condition?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario of refeeding syndrome, maximum nutritional support of 10 kcal/kg per day is recommended to prevent this condition from occurring.

Refeeding syndrome is a potentially lethal condition that can occur with rapid and excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition due to starvation, alcoholism, delayed nutritional support, anorexia nervosa, or massive weight loss in obese patients.

The patient is considered to be at risk of developing refeeding syndrome with either one or more of the following: 

  • BMI <16 kg/m2
  • Unintentional weight loss >15% within the last 3–6 months 
  • Little or no nutritional intake for more than 10 days 
  • Low potassium, phosphate or magnesium levels prior to feeding 

With excessive refeeding, there is an increased release of insulin due to the metabolic shift from fat to carbohydrate substrate. As a result, there is an increase in the cellular uptake of electrolytes including phosphate, magnesium, potassium, and calcium. Hence metabolic abnormalities are seen which include hypophosphatemia, hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia, and hypocalcemia.

These electrolyte disorders thereby result in myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, respiratory dysfunction, liver dysfunction, seizures, confusion, coma, tetany, and death.

Nutritional support should be started at a maximum of 10 kcal/kg per day, with the goal of gradually increasing levels to meet full needs within 4-7 days. Treatment includes the correction of underlying electrolyte abnormalities and nutritional support with supplementary thiamine, vitamin B, multivitamins and trace elements.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient, diagnosed with colon cancer, underwent a hemicolectomy procedure. Following the surgery, he developed persistent nausea and vomiting with significant weight loss. An abdominal CT scan with contrast showed the following findings. Resolution of symptoms was seen following weight gain in the patient. Which part of the bowel is involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of an elderly male patient presenting with persistent nausea, vomiting and significant weight loss following a hemicolectomy procedure for colon cancer with resolution of these symptoms with weight gain and CT abdomen showing reduced angle between the superior mesenteric artery and the abdominal aorta is suggestive of superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome/ Wilkie syndrome. The duodenum is involved in this condition.

Wilkie's syndrome is an acquired disorder in which the third part of the duodenum gets compressed between the superior mesenteric artery anteriorly and the aorta posteriorly, as shown in the image below. 

The normal angle between the SMA and aorta ranges from 25-60 degrees. A mesenteric fat pad is normally present between the SMA and the third part of the duodenum. This fat pad can be lost in cases of rapid weight loss and abdominal surgery, resulting in the narrowing of the above-mentioned angle.

The result is that the third part of the duodenum now gets compressed between these two vessels leading to obstructive symptoms. The common presentation is postprandial abdominal pain with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension.

Diagnosis can be made with a barium meal and follow-through or abdominal CT scan. The image below shows barium follow-through with dilatation of the duodenum and an abrupt cut-off at its third part. The cut-off coincides with the expected location of the SMA, depicted by the red line in the X-ray:

Conservative treatment for this condition includes gastric decompression, smaller meals, and postural changes such as knee-elbow position and left lateral decubitus position. Reversing the cause, such as regaining lost weight, also shows good results. If conservative management fails, a duodenojejunostomy is done.

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic lady presented to the OPD with the following skin lesion. She also gives a history of depression and unintentional weight loss over the past few months. Further examination confirms the presence of a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumour. Which of the following should be evaluated to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a 45-year-old diabetic lady with a history of depression and unintentional weight loss presenting with necrolytic migrating erythema (shown in the image) and further examination confirming the presence of a  pancreatic neuroendocrine tumour is suggestive of glucagonoma. Glucagon level >1000 pg/mL is considered diagnostic.

Glucagonoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumour of the pancreas. A majority of them are malignant at the time of presentation. They are most commonly seen arising from the pancreatic tail.

Clinically, the classic presentation of glucagonoma is with the “4 D’s”:

  • Diabetes
  • Dermatitis- a characteristic waxing and waning necrolytic migrating erythema is seen that usually appears before other symptoms.
  • Deep vein thrombosis 
  • Depression

In addition, it is marked by a severe catabolic state that results in significant weight loss, depletion of protein and fat reserves and vitamin deficiencies. 

Necrolytic migrating erythema is a characteristic skin lesion seen in glucagonoma patients usually before the appearance of other symptoms It is thought to be caused by low levels of amino acids. Therefore parenteral administration of amino acids was found to result in the disappearance of the skin lesions.

Diagnosis is established by estimating plasma glucagon levels. A level >1000 pg/mL is considered diagnostic (normal plasma glucagon level is <150 pg/mL). Hypoaminoacidemia is also a characteristic laboratory finding. 

Treatment may include long-acting somatostatin analogues like octreotide to relieve some of the clinical symptoms such as dermatitis. To counteract the effects of malnutrition and the catabolic effects of weight loss, nutritional support measures include total parenteral nutrition and supplementation with amino acids and zinc.

Surgical resection may be attempted but is often unsuccessful due to extrapancreatic malignant spread at the time of diagnosis. 

Other options:

Option A: Somatostatinoma is also a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumour characterized by steatorrhea, diabetes mellitus, hypochlorhydria, and gallstones. A fasting plasma somatostatin level >160 pg/ml is indicative of somatostatinoma.

Option B: VIPoma is characterized by watery diarrhoea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria (WDHA syndrome). It is caused by the release of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) from the tumour. Patients with VIPomas have levels ranging from 225-2000 pg/mL (normal VIP levels < 200 pg/mL)

Option D: Insulinomas are the most common pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors. They are characterized by symptoms of hypoglycemia, low plasma glucose at the time of symptoms, and relief of symptoms on glucose consumption. This is known as the Whipple's triad. C peptide levels > 1.2 μg/ml with a glucose level of <40 mg/dl are highly suggestive of insulinoma.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of glucaganoma: 4Ds

  • Diabetes – usually mild and not associated with ketoacidosis
  • Dermatitis – Necrolytic erythema migrans
  • Deep vein thrombosis
  • Depression

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Clinical features

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: Otoscopic examination in a young lady with a history of significant unintentional weight loss shows synchronous movement of the tympanic membrane with respiration. What other feature will be characteristically seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young lady with a history of significant unintentional weight loss and ENT examination showing synchronous movement of the tympanic membrane with respiration is suggestive of a patulous eustachian tube. Autophony is characteristically seen in this condition.

Autophony is the abnormal perception of one's own breath and voice sounds.

Patulous tube is a benign condition in which the eustachian tube remains abnormally patent. It is associated with weight loss (due to chronic illness), pregnancy (especially in the third trimester) and neurologic disorders like stroke and multiple sclerosis. Significant weight loss can lead to abnormal patency due to reduced tissue pressures and loss of fat deposits in the eustachian tube region. 

The most common symptom of a patulous tube is autophony. Patients also present with varying degrees of aural fullness, loud tinnitus synchronized with nasal breathing. When excessive pressure changes are transmitted to the middle ear, vertigo and hearing loss can occur.

Treatment includes weight gain and administration of potassium iodide solution. In long-standing cases, cauterization of tubes or grommet insertion is done.

Other options:

Options A and D: Popping sensations and otalgia are seen in cases of tubal blockage.

Option B: Otitis media with effusion is commonly seen in patients with cleft palate due to the high elastin content of the torus tubarius, which makes tube opening difficult.

questions.text: Which of the following inflammatory mediators is not responsible for the symptoms of cachexia and unintentional weight loss in cancer patients?
questions.solution:
Cachexia and weight loss in cancer patients have been mainly linked to the inflammatory mediators TNF-α, interleukin-1 β, and interleukin-6. Interleukin-2 does not play a role in this.

Cancer cachexia is a hypercatabolic state characterized by a loss of muscle mass that cannot be explained by a reduction in food intake. It is a severely debilitating condition marked by extreme weight loss, fatigue, muscle atrophy, anaemia, anorexia, and oedema.

Cytokines suppress feeding behaviour and decrease gastric motility, gastric emptying, and intestinal motility. TNF-α, also known as cachectin, is a primary mediator of muscle wasting. Muscle loss occurs as a result of increased degradation of major skeletal muscle structural proteins due to cytokines, which result in ubiquitination of target proteins and proteolysis via the proteasome.

Loss of fat stores in cancer patients is attributed to a protein called lipid mobilizing factor. This has been detected in the sera and urine of patients with advanced cancer and it sensitizes adipocytes to lipolytic stimuli.

Tumour necrosis factor-α levels are also elevated in several other disease states associated with cachexia and weight loss like AIDS, heart failure, rheumatoid arthritis and COPD.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a major manifestation of unintentional weight loss?
questions.solution:
Osteopenia is not considered a major manifestation of unintentional weight loss (UWL).

The four major manifestations of unintentional weight loss are

  • Anorexia (loss of appetite)
  • Sarcopenia (loss of muscle mass)
  • Cachexia (a syndrome of weight loss, loss of muscle and adipose tissue, anorexia, and weakness)
  • Dehydration

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with a history of coronary artery disease presented with recurrent postprandial abdominal pain over the last 6 months. The pain typically occurs within 30 minutes of starting the meal. The patient also reports avoiding certain food items that precipitate these symptoms, which has ultimately led to significant weight loss in the patient. Which of the following investigations is considered the best screening tool to evaluate this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 50-year-old male patient with a history of coronary artery disease presenting with a 6-month history of recurrent postprandial abdominal pain which starts within 30 minutes of starting a meal and the avoidance of certain food items that precipitate these symptoms, which has led to significant weight loss points to the diagnosis of chronic mesenteric ischemia. Duplex ultrasound is the best screening tool to evaluate this condition.

Chronic mesenteric ischemia occurs due to atherosclerosis of the celiac or mesenteric arteries. It is common in older women, and they usually have a history of smoking, coronary artery disease, cerebrovascular disease, or peripheral artery disease. 

Postprandial abdominal pain, known as intestinal angina, is caused by an imbalance between increased demand and decreased blood flow to the intestine. Pain typically begins 30 minutes after the start of a meal and lasts an hour or more. In the epigastrium, pain is felt as a deep, constant ache that can sometimes radiate to the upper left or right quadrant. 

Patients avoid eating due to postprandial pain and this leads to significant weight loss.

Duplex ultrasound's high sensitivity and specificity have made it a popular screening tool for assessing mesenteric vessels. Diagnosis is confirmed by CT angiography. Once the disease is confirmed, the patients have to be started with antiplatelets and mesenteric angioplasty and stenting should be performed.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with unintentional weight loss, sweating, and palpitations. On examination, she was found to have an enlarged thyroid gland. Radioactive iodine studies revealed the following findings. What is the definitive management in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 40-year-old woman who presented with unintentional weight loss, sweating, and palpitations with an enlarged thyroid gland on examination and radioactive iodine scan showing multiple areas of high iodine uptake is suggestive of toxic multinodular goitre. The definitive management is a total or near-total thyroidectomy.

Multinodular goitre (MNG) is more commonly observed in women. It is common in iodine-deficient regions. MNG is discordant growth with functionally and structurally altered thyroid follicles presenting as multiple nodules in the thyroid. It could present as toxic or non-toxic MNG

Clinical features:

  • Multiple nodules of different sizes are formed in both lobes, also in the isthmus, which is firm, nodular, non-tender, and moves with deglutition.
  • Patients with toxic MNG have subclinical or mild hyperthyroidism.
  • The recent increase in size signifies malignant transformation or haemorrhage.
  • Positive Kocher’s test is due to compression over the trachea (tracheomalacia/scabbard trachea) in a long-standing MNG.
  • Nodule when calcified becomes harder; necrosis softens the nodule.

Investigations:

  • Thyroid function test - suggestive of subclinical or mild hyperthyroidism.
  • Ultrasound neck identifies impalpable nodules, number, nature of nodule, and vascularity of nodule.
  • Radioactive Iodine studies show high uptake in multiple sites due to over-functioning of the toxic nodules.
  • FNAC is done from the most dominant and suspicious nodule.

Complications of MNG:

  • Secondary thyrotoxicosis 
  • Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid
  • Hemorrhage in a nodule
  • Tracheal obstruction, calcification

Treatment:

Usually, surgery is preferred after bringing the patient to a euthyroid state with the help of anti-thyroid drugs (option A). Radioactive iodine therapy (option B) is implemented for large goitres as it decreases goitre size and can ablate regions of autonomy.

Adequate thyroidectomy is essential, either total or subtotal, complete removal of diseased thyroid without retaining is considered, due to chances of high recurrence. Re-surgery for recurrent MNG is difficult due to loss of anatomical plane and fibrosis; hence total thyroidectomy is often advised. Postoperative L-thyroxine is often given to prevent any fluctuation in TSH level which may cause recurrent nodule formation.

Related Pearl: Thyroid Surgeries

  • Lobectomy - One entire thyroid lobe is removed.
  • Hemithyroidectomy - Total lobectomy of one lobe +isthmusectomy
  • Subtotal thyroidectomy - 2 x subtotal lobectomy (Leaving greater than 1 g of thyroid tissue on each lobe)+ isthmusectomy
  • Near total thyroidectomy - Total lobectomy but leaving less than 1 g of tissue adjacent to the RLN at the ligament of Berry on one lobe + isthmusectomy (also known as Hartley-Dunhill procedure)
  • Total thyroidectomy - 2 x total lobectomy + isthmusectomy

questions.text: A 50-year-old smoker presents with occasional chest pain, pain along the left arm, and ptosis. He also complains of unintentional weight loss for the past month. His chest X-ray reveals a mass at the left lung apex with the destruction of adjacent ribs. He underwent the imaging modality shown, which revealed a high uptake within the tumour. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Small cell carcinoma of the lung

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 50-year-old smoker presenting with occasional chest pain, pain along the left arm, ptosis and unintentional weight loss for the past month with a chest X-ray revealing a mass at the left lung apex with the destruction of adjacent ribs and the FDG PET-CT scan shown above revealing a high uptake within the tumour is suggestive of a Pancoast tumour (superior sulcus tumour). 

Pancoast’s tumour is a rare form of lung cancer that originates at the apex of the lung. It has a unique presentation due to the stellate ganglion, chest wall and brachial plexus involvement.

It can invade the brachial plexus (C8 and T1 commonly), resulting in a radicular distribution of pain along the ulnar nerve. Invasion of the stellate ganglion results in Horner’s syndrome which presents with ipsilateral ptosis, miosis, enophthalmos, and anhidrosis. Shoulder and chest pain on the same side can result from the invasion into the chest wall and the 1st and/or 2nd ribs. Local spread, if involving the trachea or esophagus can result in dyspnea or dysphagia. 

Investigations:

  • MRI > CT is the investigation of choice for superior sulcus tumour/ Pancoast tumour.
  • FDG-PET scan shows high uptake by the tumour cells. FDG is taken up by all metabolizing cells but more avidly by cancer cells.
  • Bronchoscopy can be done in endobronchial tumours to obtain a tissue diagnosis.

Management is summarized in the flowchart as shown below.

Other options:

Option A: Small cell lung carcinoma is a highly malignant tumour that has a strong link to cigarette smoking. Tumours may arise in major bronchi or in the periphery of the lung. The presence of neurosecretory granules and the expression of neuroendocrine markers, such as CD56 and chromogranin, indicate that the tumour is derived from neuroendocrine progenitor cells found in the lining of the bronchial epithelium.

Option B: Bronchial carcinoid tumours typically arise as central masses that grow into finger-like polypoid masses that frequently protrude into the bronchus lumen. They are associated with features of carcinoid syndrome like diarrhoea, flushing and wheezing. Biopsy would show clusters of neuroendocrine cells and positive chromogranin A staining.

Option D: Adenocarcinoma of the lung is the most common form of lung cancer. It is an invasive malignant epithelial tumour with glandular differentiation. It originates from the terminal bronchiole and is typically found in the periphery. Tumour cells frequently "crawl" along normal-appearing alveolar septa in a lepidic pattern of spread near the tumour's periphery. 

Note:

Common symptoms of lung carcinoma include a persistent cough, weight loss, dyspnea, and non-specific chest pain. But severe localized pain suggests chest wall invasion with the infiltration of an intercostal nerve. Invasion of the apical area may involve the brachial plexus and must rise the suspicion of Pancoast’s syndrome.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with a history of epigastric pain, vomiting and peripheral edema. He also gave a history of involuntary weight loss in the last 2 months. On investigation, his serum protein level was found to be low. An endoscopy was done, and an image obtained when the scope was in the stomach is shown below. The gastric aspirate showed a decrease in the acid content of the stomach. Which part of the stomach is usually spared in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 50-year-old male who presented with epigastric pain, vomiting, peripheral edema, involuntary weight loss and hypoproteinemia with a decreased acid content of the stomach (hypochlorhydria) and endoscopy showing hypertrophied gastric mucosal folds is suggestive of Ménétrier disease which usually spares the antrum of the stomach.

Menetrier disease, also called hyperplastic hypersecretory gastropathy is a disorder of the stomach characterized by enlarged rugae (gastric folds). It is common in men and the age of onset is usually between 40-60 years. In children, it is usually associated with cytomegalovirus infection and in adults the aetiology is unknown.

Clinical features include epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, anorexia, peripheral edema, and weight loss. It occurs due to excessive secretion of transforming growth factor (TGF)-α, which stimulates the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) pathway, resulting in increased proliferation of mucus cells/foveolar hyperplasia within the body and fundus, causing enlarged gastric folds. The antrum is usually spared. 

There is excessive production of mucous in the stomach which results in increased loss of proteins (hypoproteinemia), and a decreased number of parietal cells and oxyntic glands leads to hypochlorhydria. They are at an increased risk of developing gastric carcinoma.

Histopathologic examination of the stomach shows hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells, cystically dilated glands that are elongated (with a corkscrew-like appearance)

Diagnosis includes endoscopy with full-thickness deep mucosal biopsy. Treatment is mainly supportive, with intravenous albumin and parenteral nutritional supplementation. A gastrectomy may be required in severe cases. Drugs like cetuximab (a monoclonal antibody against EGFR) are also being tried.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presented with diarrhea, floating stools, and weight loss for 3 months. The biopsy of the intestine is shown below. His symptoms improved with folic acid intake. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a young man presenting with diarrhea, floating stools, and weight loss with histopathology showing partial villous atrophy and marked intraepithelial lymphocytosis indicating inflammation of lamina propria and improvement with folic acid intake is suggestive of tropical sprue.

Tropical sprue is an acquired malabsorptive condition that causes chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, weight loss, and folate and vitamin B12 malabsorption. It occurs in some tropical regions and is often considered a postinfectious complication. Diagnosis is based on a small intestinal biopsy showing villous atrophy and chronic inflammation, similar to celiac disease. However, tropical sprue is unresponsive to a gluten-free diet.

Treatment includes broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., tetracycline for up to six months) and folic acid supplementation, which can lead to improvement within weeks. Patients often recover fully if they leave the endemic area. Folic acid alone can improve symptoms and correct hematologic deficiencies, but antibiotics are typically needed for complete resolution.

Other options:

Option A: Celiac disease is a gluten-sensitive enteropathy. Patients present with iron deficiency anemia, weight loss, diarrhea, and malabsorption. A biopsy reveals blunting of the villi, crypt hyperplasia, and inflammation propria. Tissue transglutaminase is involved in the pathogenesis of this disorder. Patients respond to a gluten-free diet. The image below shows histopathological findings seen in celiac disease.

Option B: Whipple's disease is a multiorgan disease caused by the bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. It is characterized by arthralgia, arthritis, weight loss, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and psychiatric manifestations. The organism can be detected by tissue immunohistochemistry and tissue staining for PAS-positive macrophages. The below image shows the PAS stain in Whipple's disease.

Option D: Short bowel syndrome is characterized by extensive removal of the small intestine. The loss of small-bowel surface area leads to severe diarrhea, weight loss, and problems absorbing fat, protein, and carbohydrates.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used to treat type II diabetes mellitus causes weight loss?
questions.solution:
Liraglutide promotes weight loss.

NOTE:

GLP-1 analogs, pramlintide, SGLT-2 inhibitors, and metformin* cause weight loss 

DPP-4 inhibitors and alpha-glucosidase inhibitors are weight neutral drugs.

Sulfonylureas and insulin promote weight gain.

Note: *Metformin classification is a bit difficult. It can cause weight loss especially in obese patients and few authorities do consider metformin as weight neutral.

questions.text:
A patient who is a known case of alcohol dependence syndrome presents with sudden and unintentional weight loss. What is the most likely diagnosis?
  • ALP - 240 IU/L
  • S. Direct bilirubin - 1 mg/dL
  • AST/ALT - 0.5
  • Alpha fetoprotein- 600 ng/mL
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient with a history of alcohol dependence, sudden unintentional weight loss, and raised AFP is hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

HCC is the most common cause of primary liver cancer. It is more commonly seen in males, and the peak age group is between 65-70 years. The main risk factor for HCC is cirrhosis and associated chronic liver damage due to chronic infection by hepatitis B or C virus (HBV or HCV), alcohol abuse, metabolic syndrome, or hemochromatosis. The incidence of HCC is increasing worldwide. This is contributed by the increase in HCV and HBV infections, along with lifestyle disorders like obesity. Obesity is associated with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). This progresses on to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) causing cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. Thus, NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC. 

Regular surveillance, including liver imaging and monitoring of alpha-fetoprotein levels, is recommended for high-risk populations, such as those with liver cirrhosis, chronic hepatitis B or C infection, or significant alcohol consumption. Early detection of HCC can improve treatment outcomes and overall prognosis.

Very early HCC is treated by ablation. Early HCC with a single nodule is resected, but when there are multiple nodules over 3 cm, ablation or transplantation are considered. Intermediate-stage HCC is treated by chemoembolization. Transarterial chemoembolization (TACE) is used for multinodular lesions.  

Other Options:

Option A: Hepatic adenomas are benign liver tumors that are often associated with oral contraceptive use and anabolic steroid use. The patient's history of alcohol dependence and high alpha-fetoprotein levels are not consistent with hepatic adenoma. Additionally, hepatic adenomas are usually asymptomatic and do not present with sudden unintentional weight loss.

Option B: Cholangiocarcinoma is a cancer that arises from the bile ducts within the liver. While patients with alcohol dependence may have an increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma, the elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels are not typical for this type of cancer. Cholangiocarcinomas usually present with jaundice, pruritus, and abdominal pain, but sudden weight loss is less characteristic.

Option D: Alcoholic hepatitis is an inflammation of the liver caused by excessive alcohol consumption. It usually presents with jaundice, fever, and abdominal pain. While the patient's history of alcohol dependence might suggest alcoholic hepatitis, elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels and unintentional weight loss are not typical for this condition. Moreover, the AST/ALT ratio is usually greater than 2 in alcoholic hepatitis, but it is 0.5 in this case.

Related Pearl: Liver tumors - commons

  • Most common tumor overall: Metastatic tumor
  • Most common primary benign tumor: Cavernous hemangioma
  • Most common primary malignant tumor: Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Most common primary malignant liver tumor of early childhood: Hepatoblastoma
  • Most common tumor associated with arsenic / vinyl chloride: Angiosarcoma
  • Most common tumor associated with oral contraceptive / anabolic steroid: Hepatic adenoma
  • Most common tumor rupture spontaneously causing hemoperitoneum: Hepatic adenoma

questions.text: A transbronchial biopsy of a patient with fever, cough and weight loss shows the findings of the biopsy below. Which of the following chemical mediators are involved in its pathogenesis?
questions.solution:
Interferon gamma (IFN-γ) is a pro-inflammatory cytokine that is involved in the formation of granulomas. It activates macrophages to differentiate into epithelioid cells and multinucleated giant cells, which are the main components of granulomas.

IFN-γ is the most important chemical mediator involved in the pathogenesis of granulomas. It is produced by T helper 1 (Th1) cells and other immune cells in response to a variety of stimuli, including infections, autoimmune diseases, and foreign bodies.

Interferon-gamma-induced changes in the macrophages:

  1. Augmented ability of the macrophages to phagocytose and kill micro-organisms.
  2. Increased expression of class 2 MHC molecules to enhance antigen presentation.
  3. Increased secretion in presence of tumor necrosis factor, interleukin-1, and other inflammatory chemokines.
  4. Amplification of the Th1 response by producing more interleukin-12.

Granulomas are characteristic of a number of diseases, including tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, and Crohn's disease. In these diseases, IFN-γ plays a central role in the formation of granulomas, which help to contain and eliminate the offending agent. However, granulomas can also be formed in response to non-harmful stimuli, such as foreign bodies or allergens. In these cases, granulomas can be harmful and can lead to tissue damage and organ dysfunction.

B. Bradykinin: Bradykinin is a vasodilator that is involved in the inflammatory response. It is not directly involved in the formation of granulomas.

C. Complement C5a: Complement C5a is a chemoattractant that attracts neutrophils and other inflammatory cells to the site of infection or injury. It is not directly involved in the formation of granulomas.

D. Prostaglandin: Prostaglandins are a group of signaling molecules that are involved in a variety of physiological processes, including inflammation. Prostaglandins can promote or inhibit the formation of granulomas, depending on the context.

questions.text: Patients on which of the following antiepileptic drugs will experience weight loss?
questions.solution:
Topiramate causes weight loss as one of its common side effects. 

Topiramate has mixed mechanisms of action:

  • Reduces voltage gate Na+ currents
  • Activates hyperpolarizing K+ currents
  • Enhances postsynaptic GABAA current
  • Limits the activation of AMPA subtype of glutamate receptors.

Topiramate is used in focal seizures, GTCS and Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.

The side effects: 

  • Cognitive impairment
  • Weight loss
  • Fatigue
  • Renal calculi

Sodium valproate, vigabatrin (highest incidence), and carbamazepine cause weight gain.
